sentences.text: Thanks for listening to The Rest is Politics.

Now we're delighted to have an interview with the first minister of Wales, Mark Drakeford, And please don't be too surprised if we don't talk about the queen or king Charles because the interview was conducted shortly before the sad demise of her majesty.
Welcome to The Rest is Politics with me, Alastair Campbell
and me, Rory Stewart.
And a very special guest, we are absolutely delighted to welcome the 1st minister of Wales, Mark Greatford.
Mark, hello, and thank you for being here.
Very pleased to be here.
Now can I kick off?
Because every time I read about you in any sort of profile piece, the word, Corbynista, gets attached to you, and I can see from the Grievous that that probably irritates you a bit.
But I just wanna get a sense of your politics.
If if we accept that Jeremy Is, say, on the left of the party, and my old boss, Tony, is on the right of the party.
Where are you putting yourself adjacent or between them?
Well, I think in my own politics as being derived from the radical Welsh tradition.
And, you know, that can go back as far as Lloyd George and gets handed down The generations via Bevan, Michael Foote, Neil Kinnock.
It's that strand in Welsh politics, Which is to the left of the center, but, you know, all of politics in Wales is to the left of where it would be across the United Kingdom.
And insofar as I think of myself as belonging to a tradition, it is to that sort of radical strand in Bosch politics.
And, Mark, can you help help me on this because I'm obviously a an ex Tory talking to you and a lot of this is is alien to me and I'm trying to understand the world she grew up in.
So You're you're somebody who's been described as an atheist republican socialist.
Is that is that roughly true?
I'm not brave enough to be an atheist.
I'm an, I'm an agnostic.
Oh, good.
But, the other things would be true.
The other things would be true.
And when you were growing up, it was a very dominant figure, actually, even when you were an adult because you came, I think, into elected politics surprisingly late.
We're in a world where, most of the last lot of prime ministers have gotten in their forties, early fifties.
I think you didn't become an elected member till you were in your late fifties, did you?
You had a whole Separate career as an academic universities.

But I've noticed this this big figure called Jack Brooks who seems to dominate a lot of talking about the early eighties in Wales and I'd love a sense of what Labour politics in Wales felt like in the late seventies, early eighties when you were beginning to get involved, what kind of character he was And how it's changed?
I mean, how would Jack Brooks think about the Welsh Labour Party if he was to turn up today?
Maybe you could tell this.
It's a bit about Jack Brooks before you tell us a little bit Answer that question.
Yeah.
Well, I became a counselor in my twenties.
Jack was the leader of South Morgan Council during the time that I was a councilor, so I certainly saw him a very close quarters.
He was in if you've contrasted modern politics to the politics that Jack grew up in.
And it was pretty much a sort of male dominated, probably boss led Solo politics, you know, where big beasts dominated local councils across Wales.
And was he a boxer?
He if you're interested in boxing, wasn't he?
Yeah.
Yeah.
No.
He was.
He's a plasterer, by, by training.
If you if you wanted to Learn something about him.

He's all dressed up.
He's ready for a night out.
He sees a young woman, across the floor, and she's looking at him.
And, you know, he thinks, well, my mind could be turning up a bit, here.
And, you know, she comes across the floor, Tim, and says to him, oh, you're Jack Brooks, aren't you?
And you think you definitely think tonight is getting better.
And she says to him, you're the kid who used to have free school meals.
And I think it's that sort of experience, really, which shaped Hey.
One would have shaped many other people in the Labour Party.

You know, that sense that people are not to be shaped by their other gyms And that the job of the party is to provide the chances for people to be able to make the very most of their talents and their abilities.
Just one more sort of push at this before I bring back Alastair.

So

Well, I think it is part of our our history, But we are capable of amending it.

You know, I lead a labor group in the senate, which is 17 women and 13 men In it, there are 5 women in my cabinets and 4 men and women fill all the major sorts of, ministerial Physicians are not in any way confined to what you might have thought as the traditional, responsibilities that women would undertake.
So, You know, that is a very steep change to the sort of world in which, you know, my early experience of labor politics in Wales Would have been shaped.
So we are capable of amending our own history, and we need to go on doing that.
Now we don't wanna talk too much about the Richard Boris Johnson, But I got the sense of your relationship with him being very, very difficult.

What do you think the relationship between the first minister of Wales The UK prime minister should be, and what hopes do you have for a better relationship with Liz Truss and how realistic doing that is?
Well, the fundamental word is that it Needs to be respectful.
So I go to the series of, you know, different prime ministers, including conservative prime ministers.
And I think there was a very big contrast between relations with Theresa May when she was prime minister and with her Success.

I disagreed with missus May on almost anything you'd like to say and, you know, was terribly frustrated at what I thought was her fundamental Mistake in regarding Brexit as a winner takes all, sort of referendum.
But I would describe her as an instinctive democrat.

If you were in a room with her and she was prime minister, she would make a conscious effort to make sure that Anybody in the room who had a view they wanted to contribute had an opportunity to contribute to that view.
And, you know, that is a sort of instinctive respect for The range of different individuals and experiences that you will you will come across.
So I think it is perfectly possible to have Good, effective, constructive working relationships with people who are in a different party from you and occupy a different position.
But it's got to be founded on a basic sense of respect and parity of participation.
You know, Wales is a small country.
It is not the same as a country the size of England, but parity of participation is something different.
You know, every voice has a right to be heard and to be treated respectfully.
And you felt that Johnson didn't treat you with respect?
On an individual level, on the rare occasions that I had direct conversations with mister Johnson, he, you know, he he was courteous.
He He wasn't disrespectful in that way, but his approach to the future of the United Kingdom was very different.
You know, Theresa May in the final lecture in Edinburgh described the United Kingdom as a voluntary association of 4 nations.
I think that was, you know, the end of quite a long journey probably for her.
Boris Johnson believed that the way to save the United Kingdom was to, you know, assert muscular unionism.
Mhmm.

Holy boy Britain, as you might, more pejoratively put it in which The way to secure the future of the United Kingdom is to show who is boss, and, actually, that was completely counterproductive and contributes to the fragility of the United Kingdom Rather than helping it to be something which people choose to belong to, want to belong to.
Can I come in quickly on this?

You're somebody who describes yourself as a a federalist or a unionist, but I guess there were some people who were quite Shocked to to see you, as it were, get into bed with Plaid Comrie and I I wondered whether That was something that gave you any moments for pause or reflection before you did it?
Well, it could only be shocking to somebody outside Wales.
You know, my party's been in power, in Wales throughout the history of devolution, but we've never won more than 30 of the 60 seats on offer.
So we have always had to work with other individuals and other parties in order to be able to get the job Done.
We had a full coalition with, like, coming in 2007 where Rodri Morgan, one of my predecessors, was the 1st minister.
What we have learned is as a party in Wales is that working with other progressive parties is not something to regard as Unusual or difficult.
It's challenging, but it can be done.

And we've demonstrated that it can be done, and The current cooperation we have with Placomery is designed to allow us to deliver on the most radical parts of our agenda, things which I think are very difficult to do if you're a party on your own and certainly a party that has only half the seats available.
So I I know at the UK level, the idea of working across parties is regarded as, you know, somehow a failure of the system.
No.
No.
No.
No.
No.
Let me push back a little bit, Mark.
It's not not that I mean, I was part of a coalition with Lib Dems.
I think it's the problem of working with a party that's explicitly committed to independence.
Well, obviously, I fundamentally disagree with them on that point.
I believe in strong and entrenched Devolution where decisions are made as close to people as possible.

But I also believe that the United Kingdom is better off for having Wales in it, and Wales is better off of being in the United Kingdom, but that's because we choose to belong to it because we think there are important purposes that we discharge better together.
Well, I disagree with Paul Connery, on that, and we fought an election only a year or so ago where that choice was very explicitly with people.
That doesn't mean that there aren't very important things that we are able to agree on and can work together, I'll be able to see it, you know, for the benefit of the people who have elected us.

We had we had Keir Starmer on the podcast a a few weeks ago, And he I think he disappointed both of us really in that he didn't seem to share our belief that politics was now Potentially so broken that there has to be at least a debate about some pretty major political and constitutional change.
